awd_titl_txt: Electromagnetic Force Assisted Centrifugal Nanocasting for Manufacturing Thermoelectric Energy Conversion Composite Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports fundamental research on electromagnetic force assisted centrifugal casting in order to develop a fast, scalable and low cost manufacturing process for making high performance thermoelectric energy conversion composite materials. Specifically, the research will develop a physics-based predictive model for coupled electromagnetic and mechanical forces in centrifugal casting thermoelectric nanoparticle-containing semiconducting polymers with a newly designed rotary machine and conduct experiments to verify the model, test the hypothesis that incorporating nanoscale thermoelectric components into polymers to form complex composite structures will significantly enhance the energy conversion performance, evaluate the feasibility of using electromagnetic force assisted centrifugal casting to make thermoelectric energy conversion nanomaterials containing multilayer polymer/oxide nanotubes, establish the relationship between the energy conversion behavior and manufacturing conditions.

Research results will provide knowledge and understanding to meet the critical need of energy challenge for the nation. A globally competitive energy manufacturing industry will contribute to the nation's economy. Thermoelectric units with higher energy conversion efficiency and lower manufacturing cost will benefit consumers and the society. Research results will also enhance undergraduate students' learning in such courses as Independent Study and Senior Capstone Design. Training graduate students at California State Polytechnic University-Pomona, a minority-serving institution, and outreaching to local high schools will be carried out to stimulate the interest of minority students in the field of energy sustainability.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project aims at understanding the science underpinning innovative manufacturing processes and using the knowledge for discovering advanced energy conversion composite materials.

INTERLLECTUAL MERIT: Multicomponent organic/inorganic composite materials containing nanotubes, nanofibers and/or nanoparticles were made by electromagnetic force assisted centrifugal nanocasting and electrohydrodynamic nanocasting. The energy conversion behaviors of the manufactured composite materials were studied. A conducting polymer, polyaniline (PANI), loaded poly-vinylidene fluoride (PVDF) composite thin film was made to convert mechanical motion (vibration) energy to electricity. Polyaniline containing thermoelectric Bi-Te alloy nanoparticles was also made by the electromagnetic force assisted centrifugal nanocasting to convert waste heat into electricity. The uniform dispersion of nanoparticles in polymers was achieved via either the electromagnetic field assisted centrifugal casting or the electrohydrodynamic nanocasting. The new manufacturing approach, electrohydrodynamic casting, has been successfully used for preparing Sb-Te particle loaded polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofiber mat. The high temperature heat treatment converts the composite nanofiber mat to a new Sb-Te containing carbon nanofiber (CNF) composite material. Energy conversion behaviors of this material in view of converting electromagnetic wave energy to heat and converting photon energy to electricity were characterized. Strong hyperthermia and photovoltaics of the composite mat were found. The composite fiber mat may find multiple functions for photoelectric energy conversion, light sensing, and electromagnetic wave signal monitoring applications. Fundamental studies were also carried out for understanding the effects of electromagnetic field and the centrifugal force on the structure and energy conversion behaviors of the prepared composite materials.

BROADER IMPACTS: The performance of the project allows us to have obtained comprehensive understanding of the new manufacturing processes under coupled electric, magnetic and mechanical actions. The designed new manufacturing machine becomes a powerful tool for discovering novel organic/inorganic energy conversion composite materials. By bringing the research results into classroom activities, broader impact was achieved. The research materials enhanced the principal investigator’s teaching on various courses including Independent Research/Study and Senior Capstone Design. Since California State Polytechnic University Pomona is identified as a Hispanic Serving Institute (HSI), one of the meaningful outcomes lies in training students from the underrepresented groups. The research activities stimulate the interest of minority students in energy sustainability and helped create professional development opportunities for those students. The project also generated impacts on training diversified workforces and serving both the local community and international community. More than sixteen Brazilian students participated in the summer undergraduate research program. Training Master Degree graduate students and outreaching to local middle and high schools including Chaparral Intermediate School, Troy High School, Walnut High School, and Diamond Bar High School were carried out as well.


Last Modified: 06/15/2017
Modified by: Yong Gan

Images (1 of )
  • Scalable manufacturing bismuth telluride particle loaded carbon nanofiber composite by electrohydrodynamic casting has been performed to produce thick composite material mat at centimeter level. The energy conversion and sensing multiple functions of the composite material mat are demonstrated.
    Yong X. Gan
    Copyrighted
    Yong Gan
    Scalable manufacturing bismuth telluride particle loaded carbon nanofiber composite for energy conversion and sensing
  • Electrically-assisted nanocasting manufactures polyacrylonitrile (PAN) polymers first. Then they are converted into carbon nanofibers by heat treatment.
    Yong X. Gan
    Copyrighted
    Yong Gan
    Carbon nanofiber made by nanocasting
  • Polymer confined by aluminum particles converts to carbon network structure. Such network forms along the grain boundary of aluminum and it increases the corrosion resistance of the aluminum in seawater.
    Yong X. Gan
    Copyrighted
    Yong Gan
    Carbon network encapulating aluminum
  • An antimony telluride loaded carbon nanofiber composite material has been manufactured by electrohydrodynamic casting. Its thermoelectric and photoelectric energy conversion functions are also validated.
    Yong X. Gan
    Copyrighted
    Yong Gan
    Antimony telluride loaded carbon nanofiber composite material for thermoelectric energy conversion and photovoltaics
  • An electric and magnetic force assisted nanocasting machine has been established to make composite materials for thermoelectric, mechanoelectric, and photoelectric energy conversions and sensing applications
    Yong X. Gan
    Copyrighted
    Yong Gan
    Electric and Magnetic Force Assisted Nanocasting Machine
  • This project supported hundreds of Cal Poly Pomona students being involved in the research and training activities. The image shows the major effort of integrating research into education and outreach.
    Yong X. Gan
    Yong Gan
    Integrating research into education
